review.title: Morph-fitting: Fine-Tuning Word Vector Spaces with Simple Language-Specific Rules
review.abstract: Morphologically rich languages accentuate two properties of distributional vector space models: 1) the difficulty of inducing accurate representations for low-frequency word forms; and 2) insensitivity to distinct lexical relations that have similar distributional signatures. These effects are detrimental for language understanding systems, which may infer that 'inexpensive' is a rephrasing for 'expensive' or may not associate 'acquire' with 'acquires'. In this work, we propose a novel morph-fitting procedure which moves past the use of curated semantic lexicons for improving distributional vector spaces. Instead, our method injects morphological constraints generated using simple language-specific rules, pulling inflectional forms of the same word close together and pushing derivational antonyms far apart. In intrinsic evaluation over four languages, we show that our approach: 1) improves low-frequency word estimates; and 2) boosts the semantic quality of the entire word vector collection. Finally, we show that morph-fitted vectors yield large gains in the downstream task of dialogue state tracking, highlighting the importance of morphology for tackling long-tail phenomena in language understanding tasks.

metadata.title: Morph-fitting: Fine-Tuning Word Vector Spaces with Simple Language-Specific Rules

sections.heading: 2 Morph-fitting: Methodology
sections.text: In this thesis, we focus on four languages with varying degrees of morphological complexity: English (EN), German (DE), Italian (IT) and Russian (RU), which correspond to the languages of the SimLex 999 multilingual dataset. Vocabulary Wen, Wde, Wit, Wru are compiled by retaining all word forms from the four Wikipedias with a word frequency above 10, see Tab. 3. We then extract sentences of linguistic constraints from these (large) vocabularies using simple language-specific if-then-otherwise rules, see Tab. 2.4 These constraints (Sec. 2.2) are used as input for the vector space after processing ATTRACT-REPEL (outlined in Sec. 2.1).

sections.heading: 2.1 The ATTRACT-REPEL Model
sections.text: The ATTRACT-REPEL model proposed by Mrkšic ́ et al. (2017b) is an extension of the PARAGRAM process proposed by Wieting et al. (2015). It provides a general framework for incorporating similarities (e.g. successful and successful) and antonymic constraints (e.g. nimble and clumsy) into lecture word vectors. The cost function of the method consists of three terms. The first term summarizes the ATTRACT examples (xl, xr) and REPEL constraints A and R. If BA refers to the current mini-batch of ATTRACT examples, this term can be expressed as: A (BA).

sections.heading: 2.2 Language-Specific Rules and Constraints
sections.text: In fact, it is the case that most of them are in a position to go into a different world, in which they are able to move, in which they move, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live.

sections.heading: 3 Experimental Setup
sections.text: Training Data and Setup For each of the four languages we train the skip-gram with negative sampling (SGNS) model (Mikolov et al., 2013) on the latest Wikipedia dump of each language. We induce 300-dimensional word vectors, with the frequency cut-off set to 10. The vocabulary sizes | W | for each language are provided in Tab. 3.6 We label these collections of vectors SGNS-LARGE.Other Starting Distributional Vectors We also analyze the impact of morph-fitting on other collections of well-known EN word vectors. These vectors have varying vectors have different vocabulary coverage and are trained with different architectures. We test standard distributional models: Common-Crawl GloVe et al., 2014), SGNS vectors et al. (Mikolov et al., 2013) with different contexts (BOW = bag-ofwords), and training. We are.

sections.heading: 4 Intrinsic Evaluation: Word Similarity
sections.text: The first set of experiments is indeed morph-adjusted vector spaces on Word similarity benchmarks, using Spearman's rank correlation as a rating benchmark. First, we use the SimLex-999 datasets, as well as SimVerb-3500, a current pair of verb similarity datasets that show similarities between the references of 3,500 verb pairings. First, the SimLex-999 was translated by Leviant and Reichart, and second, they highlighted the similarity of native speakers. Second, we use these datasets for our multilingual reviews.

sections.heading: Comparison to Other Specialisation Methods
sections.text: We have also tried other models of post-processing specialization instead of ATTRACT-REPEL, which use the same "morphological" synonymic and antonymic constraints. We compare ATTRACT-REPEL with the retrofitting model (Faruqui et al., 2015) and counter-fit (Mrkšic ́ et al., 2017a). The results for EN, DE and IT are in Fig. 2. They clearly indicate that MFIT-AR outperforms the other two post-processors for each language. We assume that the performance difference is mainly due to context-sensitive vector space updates of ATTRACT-REPEL. Conversely, the other two models show pairs of updates that do not take into account the effects of each update on the sample pair.

sections.heading: 5 Downstream Task: Dialogue State Tracking (DST)
sections.text: The following example shows the true dialog state in a multi-turn dialog: What is good in the southern part of the southern Indian city? In slot-based systems, the application areas are specified using ontologies that define the search constraints the user can express. An ontology consists of a number of slots and their selected slot values. In a restaurant search area, sets of slot values from the 2012010s are used, including PRICE = [cheap, expensive] or FOOD = [Thai, Indian,...].The DST model is the first component of modern dialogue pipelines (Young, 2010). It is used to capture the set values expressed by the user in each dialog and to update the belief state. This probability distribution over the possible dialog states (defined by the domain ontology) is the internal estimation of the user's goals. It is used by the downstream dialog manager to select the system component to respond to the following Set (2016).

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: This year, the time has come for us to be able to go to a place where we can go to a place where we can go to a place where we can go to a place where we are.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: We have presented a novel morphological adaptation method that brings morphological knowledge in the form of linguistic constraints into word vector spaces. Results of the intrinsic word similarity tasks show that morphological adaptation improves vector spaces induced by distribution models across four languages. Finally, we have shown that the use of morphologically adapted vectors increases the performance of downstream speech understanding models that rely on word representations as traits, especially for morphologically rich languages such as German. Future work will focus on other potential sources of morphological knowledge and transfer the framework to other morphologically rich languages and downstream tasks, as well as further refinements of the algorithm after processing and selection of constraints.

RR is supported by the IntelICRI Grant: Hybrid Models for Minimally Supervised Information Extraction from Conversations. The authors thank the anonymous reviewers for their helpful suggestions.

sections.heading: Morphological Rules
sections.text: In this supplementary material, we provide a brief comprehensive overview of the simple language-specific morphological rules in English (EN), German (DE), Italian (UT) and Russian (RU). These rules were used to build the sentences of synonymous ATTRACT and antonymous REPEL constraints for our morph-fitting fine-tuning procedures. As discussed in the thesis, the linguistic constraints from the rules require only a comprehensive list of vocabulary in each language. A native speaker of any language that is used in our experiments can easily come up with these sentences of morphological rules (or at least with a reasonable subset of rules) without linguistic training. What is, the rules for German, Italian and Russian were created by non-native and non-fluent speakers who have only a passive or limited knowledge of the three languages, exemplifying the simplicity and portability of the approach.

sections.heading: English Rules
sections.text: Inflectional Synonymy: ATTRACT As discussed in the work, we rely on only two simple pairs of diffraction in English: - w2 = w1 +'s "/" ed "/" ing. "This rule leads to constraints such as (speaking, speaking), (turtle, turtles) or (clean, cleaned). - If w1.ew (" e "), then w2 = w1 [: − 1] +" ed "/" ing. "This rule leads to constraints such as (creating, creating) or (creating, creating).Derived antonymy: REPEL We assume the following standard group of" antonymy "prefixes in English: APen = {'dis', 'il'un', 'in' im ',' ir ',' mis', 'inflationary', 'anti'.

sections.heading: German Rules
sections.text: "We," he says, "must," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," "we," we, "" we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we," we, "we,

sections.heading: Italian Rules
sections.text: The first set of rules aims to capture the regular pairs of words in Italian (e.g., libro, libri) and the regular differences in gender (e.g., rapido, rapida). We rely on the simple heuristic words, which can be expressed as follows: - "If w1.ew (" a "/" e "), and take the Cartesian product on Ww1," "Ww1 · Ww1," "Ww2," "w2," "e," "o," "i," and take the Cartesian product on Ww1, "" Ww1, "" "the pairs with identical words." This rule results in pairs such as (nero) or (generazione, generazione, generazione). - If w1.ew ("ga" ca "), then w2."

sections.heading: Russian Rules
sections.text: The first set of rules in Russian aims at the regular formation of words in Russian. A few simple heuristics are used as follows: - w2 = "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "then" manifold words "/" manifold words "/" then "manifold words" / "manifold words" / "manifold words."

sections.heading: Further Discussion
sections.text: We stress that the rules listed for all four languages are not exhaustive and do not cover all possible inflection and derivative morphological phenomena. Further linguistic constraints can be solved by recourse to more complex rules for finer-grained morphological processes (e.g. irregular plural formation or irregular verbal conjugation and past participatory formation or non-standard declensions). Furthermore, the rules listed, written by non-native speakers without any linguistic training in a very short time, are not necessarily based on established linguistic theories in each language, but are rather simple heuristics aimed at grasping morphological laws.

referenceMentions.context: Word representation learning has become a research area of central importance in natural language processing (NLP), with its usefulness demonstrated across many application areas such as parsing (Chen and Manning, 2014; Johannsen et al., 2015), machine translation (Zou et al.

Word representation learning has become a research area of central importance in natural language processing (NLP), with its usefulness demonstrated across many application areas such as parsing (Chen and Manning, 2014; Johannsen et al., 2015), machine translation (Zou et al.
, 2015), machine translation (Zou et al., 2013), and many others (Turian et al.
, 2013), and many others (Turian et al., 2010; Collobert et al., 2011).
, 2013), and many others (Turian et al., 2010; Collobert et al., 2011).

Most prominent word representation techniques are grounded in the distributional hypothesis (Harris, 1954), relying on word co-occurrence information in large textual corpora (Curran, 2004; Turney and Pantel, 2010; Mikolov et al.
word level” (Tsarfaty et al., 2010), pose specific challenges for NLP.

Formalised as an instance of the post-processing semantic specialisation paradigm (Faruqui et al., 2015; Mrkšić et al., 2016), morphfitting is steered by a set of linguistic constraints derived from simple language-specific rules which describe (a subset of) morphological processes in a language.

Formalised as an instance of the post-processing semantic specialisation paradigm (Faruqui et al., 2015; Mrkšić et al., 2016), morphfitting is steered by a set of linguistic constraints derived from simple language-specific rules which describe (a subset of) morphological processes in a language.

Evaluation Setup The principal metric we use to measure DST performance is the joint goal accuracy, which represents the proportion of test set dialogue turns where all user goals expressed up to that point of the dialogue were decoded correctly (Henderson et al., 2014a).

In spirit, our work is similar to Cotterell et al. (2016b), who formulate the idea of post-training specialisation in a generative Bayesian framework.

metadata.abstractText: Morphologically rich languages accentuate two properties of distributional vector space models: 1) the difficulty of inducing accurate representations for lowfrequency word forms; and 2) insensitivity to distinct lexical relations that have similar distributional signatures. These effects are detrimental for language understanding systems, which may infer that inexpensive is a rephrasing for expensive or may not associate acquire with acquires. In this work, we propose a novel morph-fitting procedure which moves past the use of curated semantic lexicons for improving distributional vector spaces. Instead, our method injects morphological constraints generated using simple language-specific rules, pulling inflectional forms of the same word close together and pushing derivational antonyms far apart. In intrinsic evaluation over four languages, we show that our approach: 1) improves low-frequency word estimates; and 2) boosts the semantic quality of the entire word vector collection. Finally, we show that morph-fitted vectors yield large gains in the downstream task of dialogue state tracking, highlighting the importance of morphology for tackling long-tail phenomena in language understanding tasks.
